sn6.11:1.2: The Serpentine (sappinī) is probably the modern Panchane (from pañcānana, “five-mouthed”). There was a wanderer’s hermitage on its banks (AN 3.64, AN 4.30, AN 4.185).
sn6.11:1.3: Sanaṅkumāra (“Everyoung”) became a Hindu deity closely associated with the worship of Krishna. He first appears in the seventh chapter of the Chāndogya Upaniṣad. He speaks this verse also at DN 3:1.28.2, DN 27:32.2, MN 53:25.3, AN 11.10:6.1, and it was endorsed by the Buddha. He features in two extended discussions among the gods, his appearance heralded by a great light in the north (DN 18:15.1, DN 19:15.1). He also appears in DN 20:20.3.
